Name: Dimethyl Disulfide
Description: Dimethyl disulfide is an organic disulfide that is methane in which one of the hydrogens has been replaced by a methyldisulfanyl group. It has a role as a xenobiotic metabolite.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Puxbaum H, Konig G; Atmos Environ 31: 291-94 (1997) (2) Arnault I et al; Int J Environ Anal Chem 84: 75-82 (2004)
plant_concentrations.Value: Volatile organic compounds emitted from Allium ursinum, planted as ground cover, contained dimethyl disulfide; an average emission rate for this compound was measured as 0.239 ug/g-hr (per unit of ground area 14.6 ug/sq m-hr)(1).

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Dr. Duke's Phytochemical and Ethnobotanical Databases. Plants with a chosen chemical. Cymene. Washington, DC: US Dept Agric, Agric Res Service. Available from, as of Nov 6, 2013: https://www.ars-grin.gov/duke/
plant_concentrations.Table: [{'Genus species': 'Brassica oleracea var gongylodes', 'Common name': 'Kohlrabi', 'Part': 'stem', 'Concn (ppm)': 11.21}, {'Genus species': 'Allium sativum var sativum', 'Common name': 'Garlic', 'Part': 'bulb', 'Concn (ppm)': 2.5}, {'Genus species': 'Allium ampeloprasum', 'Common name': 'Elephant garlic', 'Part': 'plant', 'Concn (ppm)': nan}, {'Genus species': 'Allium cepa', 'Common name': 'Shalot', 'Part': 'bulb', 'Concn (ppm)': nan}, {'Genus species': 'Brassica oleracea var botrytis l var botrytis', 'Common name': 'Cauliflower', 'Part': 'plant', 'Concn (ppm)': nan}]

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Gossett RW et al; Marine Pollut Bull 14: 387-92 (1983) (2) Chung HY; J Agric Food Chem 47: 2280-7 (1999)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Concentrations of dimethyl disulfide were below the detection limit of 0.3 ug/L in various aquatic species (California halibut (Paralichthys californicus), scorpion fish (Scorpaena guttata), Dover sole (Microstomus pacificus), red pointer crap (Mursia gaudichaudii), ridgeback prawn (Sicyonia ingentis)). Animals were collected near a discharge from a Los Angeles County treatment plant where the effluent contained an average dimethyl disulfide concentration of 45 ug/L)(1). Dimethyl disulfide was detected in the leg, body and carapace of the Asian crab, Charybdis feriatus, at an average of 5.6, 1.6 and 11.1 ug/kg, respectively(2).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Gossett RW et al; Marine Pollut Bull 14: 387-92 (1983)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Concentrations of dimethyl disulfide in sediment samples collected near a discharge from a Los Angeles County treatment plant (effluent containing an average dimethyl disulfide concentration of 45 ug/L) were below the detection limit of 0.5 ug/kg(1).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: Verschueren, K. Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. Volumes 1-2. 4th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, NY. 2001, p. 912
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: Biogenic dimethyl disulfide emissions from soils in USA: 0.002 g sulfur/cu m/yr (Wadesville, IN, Alfisol, Sept-Oct 1977); 0.0014 g sulfur/cu m/yr (Philo, OH, Inceptisol, Oct 1977); 0.0001 g sulfur/cu m/yr (Dismal Swamp, NC, Histosol, Oct 1977); 0.0039 g sulfur/cu m/yr (Cox's Landing, NC-freshly clipped marsh, Oct 1977)
